content:
• Thursday, February 22, 2018
  • XCRA

    Xcerra ends merger deal, says CFIUS approval was unlikely

    • Xcerra (NASDAQ:XCRA) -2.6% after-hours on news it will terminate its sale to China's Hubei Xinyan Equity Investment Partnership, citing difficulty in securing U.S. approval for the deal.
    • XCRA says it has become evident that CFIUS - the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, the panel with oversight of deals that could lead to national security concerns - would not clear the $580M transaction.
    • XCRA provides testing technology for semiconductors and electronics, and the U.S. government has blocked other attempts by Chinese interests to buy makers of the chip technology used in mobile phones, military equipment and other systems.
    • Earlier: Xcerra beats by $0.02, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:10 PM
  • DOVA

    Dova prices stock offering at $32

    • Dova Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:DOVA) prices its public offering of 2.5M shares of common stock at $32 per share. Underwriters over-allotment is an additional 375K shares. Closing date is February 27.
    • Today's close was $32.78.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:33 PM
  • SNAP

    Jenner's Snap tweet raises question of accounting for celebrities

    • A decline in Snap shares (SNAP -6.1%) today that knocked $1.5B off the company's market cap is being widely attributed to one powerful tweet from social-media celebrity Kylie Jenner, though the move came amid a reiterated Sell note from MoffettNathanson and a growing pile of animosity for the company's app redesign.
    • There's no way for Snap to account for the asset value of celebrity endorsement, but maybe there should be, Jennifer Saba argues.
    • Traditional accounting already struggles with tech, she notes, and it doesn't (yet) account for the indispensability of social networks or the value built by celebrity users.
    • The company does already cite the importance of endorsements in its filings -- so perhaps those need to be an intangible asset to be written down at the right time.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:58 PM | 43 Comments
  • IMMR

    Immersion jumps 15.5% with Q4 revenue beat, upside guidance

    • Immersion (NASDAQ:IMMR) is up 15.5% after hours -- with quotes coming at what would be a 52-week high -- after it beat revenue expectations with its Q4 and narrowed its loss, along with issuing upside guidance for the full year.
    • Net loss as reported narrowed to $12.3M from a year-ago $38.1M; it includes a tax provision of $26.8M tied to a $28.1M noncash charge over full valuation against deferred tax assets.
    • On a non-GAAP basis, net loss narrowed to $6.2M from $7.9M.
    • Revenue breakout: Royalty and license, $6.66M (down 25.3%); Development, services and other, $234,000 (down 37.6%).
    • For 2018, it's anticipating revenues of $80M-$95M (well above an expected $52.2M) and non-GAAP net income of $35M-$46M (vs. consensus for a loss of $18.9M).
    • Press release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:35 PM

  • GDDY

    GoDaddy +4.6% after Q4 beats, upside guidance

    • GoDaddy (NYSE:GDDY) shares gain 4.6% aftermarket following Q4 results that beat estimates. Upside Q1 guidance has revenue from $620M to $625M (consensus: $597.43M) and FY18 guidance has $2.58B to $2.61B (consensus: $2.54B.)
    • Revenue breakdown: Domains, $281.6M (+16.1%); Hosting and Presence, $228.8M (+29.5%); Business Applications, $91.8M (+37.6%); International revenue, $207.3M (+52.9%). 
    • Key metrics: Customer count, 17.3M (+17.6%); average revenue per user, $139 (+7.4%); unlevered FCF, $109.2M (+42.6%); total bookings, $657.9M (+25.4%); net cash from operating activities, $104.3M (+17.1%); cash and equivalents, $595M; total debt, $2.48B; net debt, $1.89B.   
    • Press release

    | 5:41 PM
  • EIX

    Edison International +3% after easy Q4 earnings beat

    • Edison International (NYSE:EIX) +3.1% after-hours as it soundly beats Q4 core earnings and revenue expectations, which EIX says was driven by strong operating performance and tax benefits at Southern California Edison and better than expected cost performance at the parent company.
    • Core earnings exclude non-core losses of $481M, or $1.48/share, which mostly was related to the $448M, or $1.38/share, after-tax impairment and other charges related to the revised San Onofre settlement agreement.
    • EIX says it will provide 2018 earnings guidance after a final decision has been issued by the California Public Utilities Commission on the SoCal Edison 2018 GRC.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM

  • RDFN

    Redfin -7.7% after Q4 beats with downside guidance

    • Redfin (NASDAQ:RDFN) shares stumble 7.7% aftermarket following Q4 beats with a downside Q1 guidance that has revenue from $74.6M to $78.4M (consensus: $80.05M).
    • More Q1 guidance: Redfin Now rev. expected from $2.3M to $3.1M with net loss between $38.7M and $35.9M. Guidance includes about $4.5M in expected stock-based compensation and $1.8M of expected depreciation and amortization.
    • Key metrics: Redfin Now revenue, $5.1M; gross margin, 30% (-2 pts Y/Y); Real estate gross margin, 33% (flat); operating expenses, $31.5M (+18%); net loss, $1.8M; stock-based compensation, $3.1M (+$0.6M); depreciation and amortization, $1.9M (+$0.1M); cash and equivalents, $64M.
    • Press release
    • Previously: Redfin beats by $0.03, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
    • Correction: Corrected stock movement in headline.

  • HPE

    HPE +14.9% on Q1 beats, upside guidance, Hybrid IT +9%

    • Hewlett Packard Enterprise (NYSE:HPE) soars 14.9% aftermarket following Q1 beats with an 11.6% Y/Y revenue growth.
    • Upside Q2 guidance has EPS from $0.29 to $0.33 (consensus: $0.26) and FY18 guidance has EPS from $1.35 to $1.45 (consensus: $1.18). 
    • Revenue breakdown: Hybrid IT, $6.3B (+9% Y/Y in constant currency with a 9.6% operating margin; Compute +10%, Storage +23%, DC Networking, 25%, and Pointnext flat); Intelligent Edge, $620M (+7% with 2.9% op. margin; HPE Aruba Product +7%, HPE Aruba Services +6%); Financial Services, $888M (+5% with 8.1% op. margin; net portfolio assets +6% and financing volume +7%). 
    • Key metrics: Non-GAAP operating margin, 7.7% (-1.8 pts Y/Y); cash flow from operations, $0.1B (+$1.3B); total costs and expenses, $7.4B; cash and equivalents,  $7.7B. 
    • New capital allocation: Announces plan to return $7B to shareholders through FY19 in the form of share repurchases and a 50% dividend increase starting in Q3. 
    • Earnings call is scheduled for 5:30 PM Eastern Time with a webcast available here. 
    • Press release     
    • Previously: Hewlett Packard Enterprise beats by $0.12, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:04 PM | 1 Comment
  • PEB

    Pebblebrook Hotel tumbles 14% on soft outlook

    • Q4 adjusted FFO of $33.8M or $0.49 per share vs. $41.5M and $0.57 a year ago.
    • Adjusted EBITDA down 18.8% Y/Y to $46.8M; same-property EBITDA up 0.4% to $53.8M.
    • Same-property RevPAR down 0.1% Y/Y to $188.54.
    • 2018 adjusted FFO per share seen at $2.46 to 2.61 vs. $2.57 last year, with CEO Jon Bortz noting businesses remain cautious and Pebbelbrook (NYSE:PEB) has yet to see any material improvement in corporate travel trends.
    • The conference call is tomorrow at 10 ET.
    • Previously: Pebblebrook Hotel beats by $0.17, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
    • Shares down 14.25% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:53 PM | 5 Comments
  • HLF

    Herbalife Q4 sales up 5%; volume points down 2%; non-GAAP earnings up 15%; shares down 5% after hours

    • Herbalife (NYSE:HLF) Q4 results ($M): Net sales: 1,093.3 (+4.6%).
    • Net loss: (63.4) (-163.8%); non-GAAP net income: 98.6 (+14.5%); loss/share: (0.87) (-175.0%); non-GAAP EPS: 1.29 (+29.0%); cash flow ops (12 mo.): 590.8 (+60.8%).
    • Volume points by region: North America: 250.8 (-7.3%); Asia Pacific: 273.8 (+0.2%); EMEA: 271.8 (+4.5%); Mexico: 207.7 (-8.4%); South/Central America: 153.0 (-6.6%); China: 149.7 (+9.6%); Total: 1,306.8 (-1.8%).
    • 2018 guidance: Volume point growth: 2 - 6%; EPS: $3.82 - 4.22; non-GAAP EPS: 4.60 - 5.00.
    • Q1 guidance: Volume point growth: (3.0 - 7.0%); net sales growth (1.0) - 3.0%; EPS: $0.70 - 0.90; non-GAAP EPS: $0.90 - 1.10.
    • President Des Walsh to transition to Executive Vice-Chairman. CFO John DeSimone and Chief Health and Nutrition Officer Dr. John Agwunobi promoted to Co-President.
    • Shares are down 5% after hours on increased volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:47 PM | 37 Comments
  • HPQ

    HP +8.1% on Q1 beats, upside guidance; Personal Systems +13%

    • HP (NYSE:HPQ) get an 8.1% boost aftermarket from Q1 results that beat EPS and revenue estimates with a 14.5% Y/Y revenue growth.
    • Q2 guidance has EPS from $0.45 to $0.49 (consensus: $0.44) and FY18 has EPS from $1.90 to $2 (consensus: $1.81).
    • Revenue breakdown: Personal Systems, $9.44B (+13% Y/Y in constant currency with a 3.6% operating margin; Commercial +16% and Consumer +13%); Printing, $5.01B (+12% Y/Y with a 15.8% operating margin; Commercial hardware +73% and Consumer hardware +7%.)  
    • Key metrics: Non-GAAP operating margin, 7%; cash from operating activities, $996M; FCF, $977M; accounts receivable, $4.4B (down 2 days Q/Q); inventory, $5.7B (down 3 days Q/Q); accounts payable $12.8B (down 8 days Q/Q); gross cash, $6.7B.
    • Capital allocation: Returned $692M to shareholders in repurchases and dividends.   
    • Earnings call is scheduled for 5:35 PM Eastern Time with a webcast available here. 
    • Press release       
    • Previously: HP beats by $0.06, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:46 PM
  • ACIA

    Acacia -9.7% amid 39% drop in revenues, light Q1 guidance

    • Acacia Communications (NASDAQ:ACIA) is joining the optical-equipment earnings doldrums, with shares declining 9.7% after hours following a revenue miss in Q4 combined with dim guidance for the current quarter.
    • Revenues fell 39%, of a piece with other sales declines that rivals are seeing.
    • “While we continue to face some headwinds in the market, our fourth quarter 2017 results were in line with our expectations," says CEO Raj Shanmugaraj. The company increased gross margins and cash balance from Q3.
    • Gross margin (non-GAAP) was 44.5%. Income from operations came to $9.2M.
    • Net income was $11.1M.
    • EBITDA on an adjusted basis was $12.3M, beating an expected $11.9M.
    • For Q1, it's guiding to revenue of $67M-$74M (light of consensus for $93.2M), net income of $0.3M-$4.3M and EPS of $0.01-$0.10 (well below expectations for $0.28).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Press release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:45 PM | 9 Comments

  • GSAT

    Average-revenue boost lifts Globalstar Q4 sales by 21%

    • Globalstar (NYSEMKT:GSAT) grew sales by double digits in Q4 earnings, based on higher ARPU across core revenue streams.
    • Shares are up 5.8% on light postmarket trading volume.
    • Revenues rose nearly 21% and beat (one estimate), with service revenue making up for a decline in subscriber equipment sales.
    • Loss from operations rose to $30.3M from $16.8M, mainly due to $17.5M higher asset impairment charges.
    • Net loss shrank to $22.6M from $117.2M, primarily due to a change in noncash derivative valuation adjustments between the two Q4s.
    • Revenue breakout: Service, $26.6M (up 24.4%); Subscriber equipment sales, $2.81M (down 6.4%).
    • Service revenue by segment: Duplex, $10.1M (up 25%); SPOT, $12.59M (up 27.1%); Simplex, $3.1M (up 14.8%); IGO, $221,000 (down 12.6%).
    • ARPU by segment: Duplex, $47.43 (up from $35.49); SPOT, $14.33 (up from $11.91); Simplex, $3.16 (up from $3.03); IGO, $2.02 (down from $2.17).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Press release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:38 PM
  • INTU

    Intuit -4% after Q2 EPS beat with mixed guidance

    • Intuit (NASDAQ:INTU) drops 4% aftermarket following a Q2 EPS beat with in-line revenue.  Intel previously dropped its Q2 outlook due to a later tax season. Revenue came in at the low end of that guidance and EPS at the higher end.
    • Mixed Q3 guidance has revenue from $2.785B to $2.835B (consensus: $2.75B) with EPS from $4.57 to $4.62 (consensus: $4.68). Non-GAAP operating income expected from $1.535B to $1.555B. 
    • FY18 guidance reaffirmed at revenue of $5.64B to $5.74B (consensus: $5.71B) with EPS of $5.30 to $5.40 (consensus: $5.37). Non-GAAP operating income expected between $1.885B and $1.935B.  
    • QuickBooks metrics: Added 275K QuickBooks Online subscribers in quarter, bringing total to over 2.8M. Self-Employed subscribers grew to 490K, up from 425K last quarter and 180K last year. 
    • Capital allocation: Completed three acquisitions with cash and other considerations totaling $400M, repurchased $83M in shares with $1.3B remaining in the authorization program, and approved a $0.39/share dividend payable on April 18. 
    • Earnings call is scheduled for 4:30 PM Eastern Time with a webcast available here. 
    • Press release     
    • Previously: Intuit beats by $0.01, revenue in-line (Feb. 22)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM | 2 Comments

  • MELI

    Free shipping whacks margins at MercadoLibre

    • MercadoLibre (NASDAQ:MELI) reports gross merchandise volume increased 63% to $3.62B in Q4.
    • Successful items per unique buyer rose 17% to 4.6.
    • Gross profit margin was recorded at 46.5% of sales vs. 63.5% a year ago. The margin compression was caused by increases in costs associated with the company's free shipping and loyalty programs.
    • The company doubled revenue in Mexico during the quarter.
    • MELI -2.57% AH to $359.97.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:22 PM | 7 Comments
  • TTD

    Trade Desk +8.1% as revenues, profits soar and top consensus

    • The Trade Desk (NASDAQ:TTD) is up 8.1% in postmarket trade after Q4 earnings beat expectations on top and bottom lines and the company's revenue guidance tops Street forecasts as well.
    • Revenue grew 42% and topped $100M for the quarter, while net income swelled 63% to $16.8M.
    • Gross spend on the platform rose 51% Y/Y, to $1.55B-plus.
    • EBITDA of $39.5M was up 38.1% and beat an expected $35.1M.
    • It ended the year with 657 active customers, and retention over 95%.
    • For Q1, it's guiding to revenue of $73M (above consensus for $64.4M) and EBITDA of $7.5M (in line); for the full year, it sees total gross spend of at least $2.1B, revenue of at least $403M (above expected $394.5M) and EBITDA of $117M, about 29% of revenue (vs. consensus for $120.4M).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Press release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:19 PM | 12 Comments

  • SM

    SM Energy -10% amid flat production guidance, higher planned capex

    • SM Energy (SM -9.6%) plunges even after reporting a smaller than expected Q4 loss, as investors apparently are concerned about its 2018 operating plan and guidance.
    • SM plans ~$1.27B in capital spending for 2018, up from $936M spent in 2017, but guides FY 2018 production of 42M-46M boe after 44.5M boe in total output last year.
    • The company forecasts 130 net wells drilled in 2018, up from 123 in 2017, while completing 100 of the wells, down from 111 completed in 2017.
    • SM said in its earnings conference call that its 2018 focus will center on cash flow, not oil and gas volumes, and will "target substantial growth in cash flow along with a reduction in net debt-to-EBITDAX to ~2.5x."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM | 11 Comments
  • GBTC

    Today in crypto: Dudley decries mania, The New Yorker takes a shot

    • Soon to be a private citizen again, outgoing Federal Reserve Bank of New York President Bill Dudley warned of a dangerous speculative mania surrounding cryptocurrencies. His comments come one day after Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said bitcoin was a failure both as a currency and store of wealth.
    • The New Yorker's Anna Wiener argues crypto is essentially a last chance at riches club for those (nearly always men) who missed out on the tech boom.
    • Down below $10K earlier this session, Bitcoin has clawed back some losses, now off 3.5% to $10.1K.
    • Related tickers: OTCQX:GBTC, COIN, RIOT, OSTK, SSC-OLD, MARA, UEPS, OTC:BITCF, XNET, GROW, OTCPK:BTSC, OTCQB:BTCS, OTCQB:MGTI, OTCPK:BTLLF SRAX, OTCPK:GAHC, OTC:ARSC, OTCPK:USTC, OTCPK:BLKCF, COINB, OTCPK:LFIN
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 28 Comments
  • AMPE

    Ampio continues slide, down 10%

    • Ampio Pharmaceuticals (AMPE -10.2%) slips on below-average volume. Shares have lost over 31% of their value this week.
    • Today, Seeking Alpha published an article from new contributor Night Market Research questioning the viability of lead drug Ampion relative to competitors and the need for further financing.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:50 PM | 1 Comment
  • INTC

    Intel didn't tell U.S. gov. about flaws until news went public

    • Intel (INTC) didn’t inform U.S. officials about the Meltdown and Spectre chip flaws until the flaws leaked publicly.
    • Alphabet (GOOGL -0.3%) had notified Intel about the flaws six months earlier.   
    • The timeline details came out in letters that Intel, Alphabet, and Apple sent to Rep. Greg Walden in response to his questions. 
    • Alphabet says it informed Intel, AMD (AMD +0.9%), and SoftBank’s ARM about the problems last June and gave the companies 90 days to fix the problem before publicly disclosing the flaws. Alphabet left the decision to inform the government in the hands of the chipmakers. 
    • Intel says it didn’t inform the government’s cyber security officials because there wasn’t any evidence of hacking.    
    • Previously: SEC releases new guidelines for cybersecurity risk disclosures (Feb. 21)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:41 PM | 102 Comments
  • GEN

    Genesis HealthCare's revamped finances fail to excite investors; shares down 29%

    • Genesis HealthCare (GEN -28.8%) slumps on more than triple normal volume in apparent reaction to its new financing commitments.
    • The company has secured a five-year $555M asset based lending (ABL) facility from MidCap Financial Trust consisting of a $325M first lien term loan, a $200M first lien credit revolver and a $30M overline facility. The first two will bear 90-day LIBOR + 6% while the overline will bear 90-day LIBOR + 11%. Proceeds will be used to repay and replace its current $525M credit revolver scheduled to mature on February 2, 2020. The agreement should close by March 9.
    • It has also locked in a $40M expansion to its existing $124M term loan.
    • Annual cash rent commitments have been reduced by $54M and annual cash interest by over $8M.
    • The company says it should be in compliance will all financial covenants in its material lease and credit agreements as of year-end 2017, subject to closing the contracts in process.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:38 PM

    • CHK's Q4 production rose to 593K boe/day, ahead of the analyst consensus forecast of 581K boe/day and 575K boe/day in the year-ago quarter, and the company says it expects to grow production this year by 1%-5%.

  • AAPL

    Ireland expects to collect $16B from Apple; Apple Pay has 127M users

    • Ireland expects to collect a final tax bill of around $16B from Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), according to Revenue Commissioners’ chairman Niall Cody.
    • Cody’s office has to calculate the bill and turn it over to the European Commission, which ordered Ireland to collect the money.
    • Cody says more than 95% of the calculations are finished and the final tally will go to the European Commission before the end of April.
    • Apple Pay now has 127M global active users, up from 62M last year, according to Loup Ventures estimates.
    • Despite the growth, only about 5% of U.S. iPhones have Apple Pay activated compared to 11% of international iPhones. (Mobile payments are more popular and widely supported in Europe.)
    • Apple Pay availability among the top 100 U.S. retailers: 14 stores accepted on desktop, 24 on mobile, and 24 in the store’s app.
    • Over 2.7K banks now support Apple Pay, up 41% on the year.
    • Apple shares are up 0.7%.

  • QCOM

    Qualcomm sends shareholder letter about Broadcom and NXP

    • Qualcomm (QCOM -0.9%) sends a letter to shareholders concerning the reduced Broadcom (AVGO +1.1%) bid and the amended agreement to acquire NXP Semiconductors (NXPI +0.1%).  
    • Key Broadcom quote: “The Qualcomm Board is highly confident in our ability to deliver $6.75-7.50 in FY19 Non-GAAP EPS. At any realistic multiple, that would result in a value for Qualcomm well in excess of even an $82.00 proposal. Moreover, the value to Qualcomm stockholders of executing our growth plan is not only higher but carries far less risk than Broadcom's proposal. We are unwilling to give Broadcom an option at $79.00 per share for 18 months while we deliver on our strategy, as 5G gains momentum and NXP is integrated.”
    • Qualcomm says the board decided that “Qualcomm is far more valuable with NXP than without” and notes that NXP’s non-GAAP operating income has increased 20%, which means the higher $127.50/share price is actually a lower multiple than the original $110/share offer. 
    • Qualcomm urges shareholders to vote for its board nominees at the annual meeting instead of Broadcom’s nominees. 
    • Qualcomm’s annual meeting is scheduled for March 6.

  • CHK

    Crude oil, energy equities rise after surprise inventory drop

    • Crude oil prices are climbing, reversing earlier losses, after U.S. crude stockpiles fell unexpectedly by 1.61M barrels in the week ended Feb. 16, compared with analyst consensus for a 1.8M barrel increase.
    • Oil in storage in Cushing, Okla., the delivery point for Nymex WTI futures, dropped by 2.7M barrels, and WTI crude currently +2.2% at $63.03/bbl; Brent crude +1.7% at $66.52/bbl.
    • “Even though refinery runs dropped below 16 million barrels per day for the first time since the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, lower net imports have resulted in a draw,” says Clipper Data director of commodity research Matt Smtih. “The big jump in crude exports appears to have been because the EIA included the first export cargo from LOOP in last week’s number."
    • Energy (XLE +2.2%) is by far today's top gainer among industry groups; some of the biggest movers are CHK +22.8%, WLL +25.5%, GPOR +17%, XOM +2.2%, COP +2.9%, OXY +2.1%, APC +3.1%, HES +4.1%, MUR +4.3%, ETP +4.2%, ETE +3.5%, EOG +2.5%, RIG +4.8%, SWN +8.8%.
